meanings: Fire; the physical element of fire.
The Vedic god of fire; considered the messenger between gods and humans, the mouth of the gods to which sacrifices are offered.
Gastric fire, digestive power.
One of the eight guardians of the world (Dikpalas), regent of the southeast.
The number three (associated with the three sacred fires).
Name of several plants, including Plumbago Zeylanica (Chitraka).
agni.etymology: √añc (to move tortuously, to blaze), with suffix -ni. Related to Latin 'ignis' and English 'ignite'.

meanings: Tranquillity, calmness, composure, quiet, serenity, peacefulness, absence of disturbance.
Peace (between individuals or nations); reconciliation; concord; harmony.
Cessation, rest, repose, abatement, alleviation (of pain or sorrow etc.).
Extinction, annihilation, destruction (of disease, sins, etc.).
Release from transmigration, final beatitude, emancipation.
Auspiciousness, good fortune.
Appeasement, propitiation, expiation, atonement.
A ceremony for averting evil, pacifying deities, or counteracting hostile influences; an expiatory rite.
A form of Durga.
Name of several plants (e.g., *Curcuma zerumbet*, *Costus speciosus*).
Final benediction uttered at the close of a Vedic recitation or ceremony: Oṃ śāntiḥ śāntiḥ śāntiḥ
Quietism, the state of mind which regards equanimity or indifference to all worldly concerns as the supreme good.
Kings
Rulers of the earth
महीशाः।.etymology: Compound of मही (mahī) 'earth, land' + ईश (īśa) 'lord, ruler'

meanings: Law, custom, ordinance, statute.
Duty, religious or moral merit, virtue, righteousness.
Prescribed conduct, mode of life.
Essential quality, characteristic property.
Nature, disposition, state.
Justice.
Right (in law).
Religious practice or usage.
A meritorious act, a good work.
The doctrine professed in a religion, religious truth.
Usage, practice, custom, established rule.
In philosophy, an element of existence; an attribute, quality, form, or condition.
As a technical term in Buddhism, referring to the cosmic law and order and also the teachings of the Buddha.
dharma.etymology: √dhṛ (to hold, support, maintain) + -man (suffix forming abstract nouns). Thus, 'that which holds, supports, maintains'.

meanings: Wind, air; the element air, one of the five elements (pañca-bhūtāni).
The god of wind, often regarded as a regent of the north-west quarter; he is identified with Pavan and Prana.
Breath; the vital air or principle of life.
Name of a class of demi-gods (sometimes reckoned as thirty-three).
A disease of the windy humour, rheumatism, gout, paralysis.
The son of Anjana, and father (spiritually) of Hanuman; considered an incarnation of Shiva in some accounts.
The number 'forty-nine' (alluding to the forty-nine winds according to some authorities).
A particular vital air or energy current within the body (often referred to as a 'prana').
vayu.etymology: Root √vā ('to blow, move'); related to Latin 'ventus', English 'wind'.
